subject: Gardening
title: The Sacred Groves of Ancient Greece
description: A 60-second lesson on The Sacred Groves of Ancient Greece.

hook.text: The first Greek philosophers didn't teach in classrooms. They taught in sacred gardens called groves.

buildup.text: Plato's Academy was literally a gardenâ€”an olive grove sacred to the goddess Athena on the outskirts of Athens.

discovery.text: Aristotle's Lyceum had a peripatosâ€”a covered walkway among trees where he taught while strolling.

twist.text: Epicurus bought a garden specifically for his school. His philosophy of simple pleasures was literally rooted in plants.

climax.text: Western philosophy was born in gardens. The connection between thinking and green space is literally foundational.

punchline.text: Philosophy grew in a garden before any classroom.

quiz.question: Where did Plato establish his famous Academy?
options: In a stone building in central Athens
In a sacred olive grove on the outskirts of Athens
In the Roman Forum's public square
